document_metadata.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: SIRT1 is one of seven identified sirtuins, an evolutionarily conserved proteins with NAD+-dependent deacetylase activity that participate in numerous cell activities including cellular metabolism[5].

links.evidence: SIRT1 is one of seven identified sirtuins, an evolutionarily conserved proteins with NAD+-dependent deacetylase activity that participate in numerous cell activities including cellular metabolism[5].

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: SIRT1 overexpression did not decrease mutant Htt levels (Supplementary Fig. 1a), but significantly delayed the onset and slowed the progression of motor deficits in HD mice (Fig. 1c).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Overexpression of SIRT1 did not decrease mutant Htt expression in BACHD mice (Supplementary Fig. 1b), but significantly attenuated motor deficits, as indicated in both accelerating rotarod tests and open field assays. (Fig. 1g-h).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Importantly, overexpression of SIRT1 significantly attenuated the magnitude of brain atrophy in both striatum and neocortex (Fig. 1d-f).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Notably, in vivo structural MRI scans in 15-month-old mice showed significant brain atrophy in the striatum and neocortex that was partially ameliorated by SIRT1 overexpression in BACHD mice (Fig. 1i-j), suggesting that SIRT1 overexpression also attenuates neurodegeneration in BACHD mice.

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: These results demonstrate that increased expression of SIRT1 attenuates neurodegeneration and improves motor function in HD-like mice.

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Over expression of SIRT1 significantly attenuated hyperglycemia (Supplementary Fig. 2a), improved glucose tolerance (Supplementary Fig. 2 b-c) and attenuated weight loss in N171-82Q HD mice (Supplementary Fig. 2d).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Over expression of SIRT1 significantly attenuated hyperglycemia (Supplementary Fig. 2a), improved glucose tolerance (Supplementary Fig. 2 b-c) and attenuated weight loss in N171-82Q HD mice (Supplementary Fig. 2d).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Using Oxymax metabolic cages to measure energy expenditure continuously for a week and monitoring daily food intake, we found that SIRT1 overexpression mainly counteracted the negative effect of mutant Htt on food intake (Supplementary Fig. 2e) but did not affect energy expenditure (Supplementary Fig. 2f).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: SIRT1 overexpression did not alter insulin levels in control mice (318.6 Â±83.7 pg/ml in SIRT1 mice vs 315.4Â±51.5 pg/ml in WT mice, mean Â± S.E.M., n=10), but significantly reduced insulin levels in HD mice (308.9 Â± 34.4 pg/ml in HD mice vs 149.1 Â± 6.8 pg/ml in SIRT1/HD mice, mean Â± S.E.M., n=10).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Since SIRT1 attenuated hyperglycemia and decreased insulin levels in HD mice, these results indicate that SIRT1 improves insulin sensitivity in HD mice.

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Intriguingly, SIRT1 overexpression did not extend the life span in N171-82Q HD mice.

links.evidence: In addition, SIRT1 overexpression did not alter aggregation of mutant Htt (Supplementary Fig. 4), suggesting that aggregation does not play a major role in neuroprotective effects of SIRT1 in our models.

links.evidence: Importantly, SIRT1 restored DARPP32 levels in both HD models (Fig. 2a-b), suggesting that SIRT1 protects striatal neurons against mutant Htt by preservation of DARPP32 levels in medium spiny neurons.

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: SIRT1 is one of seven identified sirtuins, an evolutionarily conserved proteins with NAD+-dependent deacetylase activity that participate in numerous cell activities including cellular metabolism[5].

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Whether SIRT1 has protective role in mammalian HD remains undefined, however, as results from lower organisms such as Caenorhabditis elegans [13] and Drosophila melanogaster [14] are contradictory; for example, overexpression of sir2, an ortholog of human SIRT1, suppressed mutant huntingtin (Htt)-induced neurotoxicity [13], whereas overexpression of sir2 in drosophila showed no significant protection [15].

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Using Oxymax metabolic cages to measure energy expenditure continuously for a week and monitoring daily food intake, we found that SIRT1 overexpression mainly counteracted the negative effect of mutant Htt on food intake (Supplementary Fig. 2e) but did not affect energy expenditure (Supplementary Fig. 2f).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: Using a specific antibody that detects acetylated p53 at lysine 382, we found increased levels of acetylated-p53 in cells expressing mutant Htt compared to those expressing wild-type Htt, suggesting that the mutant protein interfered with SIRT1 deacetylase activity (Fig. 4i).

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: DARPP-32 (dopamine- and cyclic AMP-regulated phosphoprotein of a molecular weight of 32 kDa) is a fundamental component of the dopamine-signaling cascade, [30,31] and HD pathology is marked by extensive loss of medium spiny striatal neurons that express high levels of DARPP32; therefore, DARPP32 can serve as a marker of neuronal loss as well as neuronal dysfunction in HD [32,33]

links.evidence: BDNF signaling in the brain also plays an important role in regulating glucose metabolism [43] and administration of BDNF in brain reduces blood glucose levels in diabetic mice [44].

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: FOXO3a is a ubiquitously expressed mammalian forkhead transcription factor that is highly expressed in adult brain, and recent work indicates that FOXO3a has important roles in neuronal survival under both basal conditions and disease conditions [51-53].

citation.name: Neuroprotective role of Sirt1 in mammalian models of Huntington's disease through activation of multiple Sirt1 targets.

links.evidence: In HD cells, overexpression of FOXO3a increased levels of BDNF and DARPP32, whereas knockdown of FOXO3a further decreased DARPP-32 levels (Supplementary Fig. 7a-c), suggesting that FOXO3a deficiency may contribute, either directly or indirectly, to mutant Htt-induced abnormalities in BDNF and DARPP-32.
